channel.title: NASA Image of the Day
channel.description: The latest NASA "Image of the Day" image.

item.title: Journey to Space in a Vacuum Chamber
item.description: Supporting the testing of electric propulsion and power systems, VF-5 has the highest pumping speed of any electric propulsion test facility in the world.

item.title: Mount St. Helens at 35
item.description: On May 18, 1980, Mount St. Helens gave way to a cataclysmic flank collapse, avalanche, and explosion that killed 57 people and displaced many others. The event dramatically reshaped the volcano and surrounding land in southwest Washington.

item.title: Astronauts at Work on the International Space Station
item.description: NASA astronauts Scott Kelly (left) and Terry Virts (right) work on a Carbon Dioxide Removal Assembly (CDRA) inside the station's Japanese Experiment Module.

item.title: Green Aviation Project Tests Shape Changing Wing Flaps
item.description: A NASA F-15D flies chase for the G-III Adaptive Compliant Trailing Edge (ACTE) project. The ACTE experimental flight research project is a joint effort between NASA and the U.S. Air Force Research Laboratory to determine if advanced flexible trailing-edge wing flaps can both improve aircraft aerodynamic efficiency and reduce airport-area noise.

item.title: May 13, 1992, Record-Setting Spacewalk on Shuttle Endeavour's First Mission
item.description: On May 13, 1992, following the successful capture of the Intelsat VI satellite, three astronauts continue moving the 4.5 ton communications satellite into the space shuttle Endeavour's cargo bay. The sections of Earth which form the backdrop for the scene are blanketed with thousands of square miles of clouds.

item.title: Early Morning Sunrise Over the Grand Canyon
item.description: From the International Space Station, NASA astronaut Terry Virts took this photograph of an early morning sunrise over the Grand Canyon and posted it to social media on May 10, 2015. Because the station completes each trip around the globe in about 92 minutes, the crew experiences 16 sunrises and sunsets each day.

item.title: Serene Saturn
item.description: From a distance Saturn seems to exude an aura of serenity and peace.

item.title: Cloudy Earth
item.description: Earth’s cloudy nature is unmistakable in this global cloud fraction map, based on data collected by the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA's Aqua satellite. This version of the map shows an average of all of the satellite’s cloud observations between July 2002 and April 2015.

item.title: Engineers Clean Mirror with Carbon Dioxide Snow
item.description: Engineers are using carbon dioxide snow to clean James Webb Space Telescope's mirrors without scratching them.

item.title: Solar Dynamics Observatory Sees 'Cinco de Mayo' Solar Flare
item.description: NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory, which watches the sun constantly, captured these images of a significant solar flare – as seen in the bright flash on the left – peaking at 6:11 p.m. EDT on May 5, 2015. Each image shows a different wavelength of extreme ultraviolet light that highlights a different temperature of material on the sun.

item.title: Trajectory of Alan Shepard's Historic Flight
item.description: Fifty-four years ago on May 5, 1961 only 23 days after Yuri Gagarin of the then-Soviet Union became the first person in space, NASA astronaut Alan Shepard launched at 9:34 a.m. EDT aboard his Freedom 7 capsule powered by a Redstone booster to become the first American in space. His historic flight lasted 15 minutes, 28 seconds.

item.title: Mimas Stares Back
item.description: The great eye of Saturn's moon Mimas, a 130-kilometer-wide (80-mile) impact crater called Herschel, stares out from the battered moon. Several individual ringlets within the F ring are resolved here, and the small moon Atlas is also seen faintly outside the main rings.

item.title: Ten-Engine Electric Plane Prototype Takes Off
item.description: A team at NASA's Langley Research Center is developing a concept of a battery-powered plane that has 10 engines and can take off like a helicopter and fly efficiently like an aircraft. The prototype, called Greased Lightning or GL-10, is currently in the design and testing phase.

item.title: Overview of MESSENGER Spacecraft's Impact Region on Mercury
item.description: On April 30th, this region of Mercury's surface will have a new crater! Traveling at 3.91 kilometers per second (over 8,700 miles per hour), the MESSENGER spacecraft will collide with Mercury's surface, creating a crater estimated to be 16 meters (52 feet) in diameter.

item.title: April 29, 1990, Shuttle Discovery Lands Following Hubble Deployment Mission
item.description: On April 29, 1990, the Space Shuttle Discovery approaches for landing on a concrete runway at Edwards Air Force Base to complete a highly successful five-day mission during which the Hubble Space Telescope was released into orbit.

item.title: Astronaut Scott Kelly Speaks at Shuttle Enterprise Dedication Ceremony
item.description: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly delivers remarks from onboard the International Space Station during the Space Shuttle Enterprise dedication ceremony Monday, April 27, 2015, at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in New York City. Enterprise was dedicated to the fallen crews who gave their lives in pursuit of space exploration.

item.title: Unmasking the Secrets of Mercury
item.description: To learn more about the minerals and surface processes on Mercury, instruments aboard NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft have been collecting surface measurements since MESSENGER entered Mercury orbit on March 17, 2011.

item.title: April 25, 1990, Deployment of the Hubble Space Telescope
item.description: In this April 25, 1990, photograph taken by the crew of the STS-31 space shuttle mission, the Hubble Space Telescope is suspended above shuttle Discovery's cargo bay some 332 nautical miles above Earth.

item.title: Celestial Fireworks
item.description: The brilliant tapestry of young stars flaring to life resemble a glittering fireworks display in the 25th anniversary NASA Hubble Space Telescope image, released to commemorate a quarter century of exploring the solar system and beyond since its launch on April 24, 1990.

item.title: NASA Tail Technology Could Someday Reduce Airplane Fuel Use
item.description: In this photo taken from a chase plane, the Boeing ecoDemonstrator 757 flight test airplane --with NASA's Active Flow Control technology installed on the tail -- makes a final approach to King County Boeing Field in Seattle, Washington.

item.title: A Sky View of Earth From Suomi NPP
item.description: This composite image of southern Africa and the surrounding oceans was captured by six orbits of the NASA/NOAA Suomi National Polar-orbiting Partnership spacecraft on April 9, 2015, by the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) instrument. Tropical Cyclone Joalane can be seen over the Indian Ocean.

item.title: Reflecting on a Spacecraft Arrival
item.description: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, currently on a one-year mission on the International Space Station, posted this image of the successful capture of the SpaceX Dragon spacecraft with the space station's robotic arm.

item.title: White Dwarf May Have Shredded Passing Planet
item.description: In this Chandra image of ngc6388, researchers have found evidence that a white dwarf star may have ripped apart a planet as it came too close. When a star reaches its white dwarf stage, nearly all of the material from the star is packed inside a radius one hundredth that of the original star.

item.title: Multi-Utility Technology Testbed Aircraft On the Runway
item.description: The X-56A Multi-Utility Technology Testbed (MUTT) is greeted on an Edwards Air Force Base runway by a U.S. Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL) team member.

item.title: Honoring Jackie Robinson
item.description: "Honoring #JackieRobinson today! #42" wrote NASA astronaut Terry Virts from the cupola of the International Space Station.

item.title: SpaceX Launches NASA Cargo and Research To International Space Station
item.description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station carrying the Dragon resupply spacecraft on the sixth commercial resupply services mission to the International Space Station.

item.title: Solar Arrays on the International Space Station
item.description: Expedition 43 Flight Engineer Samantha Cristoforetti of the European Space Agency (ESA) photographed the giant solar arrays on the International Space Station on Feb. 12, 2015.

item.title: Mission Control, Houston, April 13, 1970
item.description: Apollo 13, NASA's third crewed mission to the moon, launched on April 11, 1970. Two days later, on April 13, a fault in the electrical system of one of the Service Module's oxygen tanks produced an explosion that caused both oxygen tanks to fail and also led to a loss of electrical power

item.title: Layers and Dark Dunes on the Surface of Mars
item.description: This image of a circular depression on the surface of Mars was acquired on Jan. 5, 2015 by the High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment (HiRISE) camera on NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO).

item.title: The Mercury Astronauts
item.description: On April 9, 1959, NASA's first administrator, Dr. Keith Glennan, announced the names of the agency's first group of astronauts at a news conference in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Sea Ice Off East Antarctica's Princess Astrid Coast
item.description: On April 5, 2015, the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’s Terra satellite acquired this natural-color image of sea ice off the coast of East Antarctica’s Princess Astrid Coast.

item.title: Searching for Water in the Solar System and Beyond
item.description: As NASA missions explore our solar system and search for new worlds, they are finding water in surprising places.

item.title: International Space Station Flyover of Australia
item.description: From the International Space Station, NASA astronaut Scott Kelly took this photograph over Australia and posted it to social media on April 6, 2015.

item.title: Experimental Wing Tests Electric Propulsion Technologies
item.description: Leading Edge Asynchronous Propeller Technology (LEAPTech) project researchers at NASA's Armstrong Flight Research Center are performing ground testing of a 31-foot-span, carbon composite wing section with 18 electric motors.

item.title: Curiosity Sees Prominent Mineral Veins on Mount Sharp, Mars
item.description: This March 18, 2015 view from the Mast Camera (Mastcam) on NASA's Curiosity Mars rover shows a network of two-tone mineral veins at an area called "Garden City" on lower Mount Sharp.

item.title: Space Station Flies Over Super Typhoon Maysak
item.description: Typhoon Maysak strengthened into a super typhoon on March 31, reaching Category 5 hurricane status on the Saffir-Simpson Wind Scale. ESA Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti captured this image while flying over the weather system on board the International Space Station.

item.title: Boarding the Soyuz Spacecraft on Launch Day
item.description: Expedition 43 Russian cosmonaut Mikhail Kornienko of the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos), top, NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, center, and Russian cosmonaut Gennady Padalka of Roscosmos wave farewell as they board the Soyuz TMA-16M spacecraft ahead of their launch to the International Space Station, Friday, March 27, 2015.

item.title: One-Year Crew Launches to International Space Station
item.description: Media photograph the Soyuz TMA-16M spacecraft as it launches to the International Space Station.

item.title: Hubble Views a Galaxy on Edge
item.description: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image shows an edge-on view of the spiral galaxy NGC 5023.

item.title: Pushing the Boundaries of Propelling Deep Space Missions
item.description: Solar Electric propulsion system will propel the first mission to redirect an asteroid.

item.title: Soyuz Spacecraft Rolled Out For Launch of One-Year Crew
item.description: The Soyuz TMA-16M spacecraft is seen after is was rolled out by train to the launch pad at the Baikonur Cosmodrome, Kazakhstan, Wednesday, March 25, 2015.

item.title: Expedition 43 Soyuz Rolls Out for Launch
item.description: The Soyuz TMA-16M spacecraft is rolled out by train to the launch pad at the Baikonur Cosmodrome, Kazakhstan, Wednesday, March 25, 2015.

item.title: Mars 'Marathon Valley' Overlook
item.description: This view from NASA's Opportunity Mars rover shows part of "Marathon Valley," a destination on the western rim of Endeavour Crater, as seen from an overlook north of the valley.

item.title: March 23, 1965 Launch of First Crewed Gemini Flight
item.description: The first crewed Gemini flight, Gemini III, lifted off Launch Pad 19 at 9:24 a.m. EST on March 23, 1965. The spacecraft "Molly Brown" carried astronauts Virgil I. "Gus" Grissom, command pilot, and John W. Young, pilot, on three orbits of Earth.

item.title: Solar Eclipse From the International Space Station
item.description: Expedition 43 Flight Engineer Samantha Cristoforetti took a series of photographs of the March 20, 2015 solar eclipse from the International Space Station.

item.title: Astronaut Spacesuit Testing for Orion Spacecraft
item.description: Engineers and technicians at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston are testing the spacesuit astronauts will wear in the agency’s Orion spacecraft on trips to deep space. On March 17, members of the Johnson team participated in a Vacuum Pressure Integrated Suit Test to verify enhancements to the suit will meet test and design standards.

item.title: Vanguard Satellite, 1958
item.description: Vanguard 1, the world’s first solar-powered satellite, launched on St. Patrick’s Day (March 17) 1958.

item.title: Groovy Rings of Saturn
item.description: From afar, Saturn's rings look like a solid, homogenous disk of material.

item.title: Launch of Magnetospheric Multiscale Spacecraft Aboard Atlas V Rocket
item.description: The United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with NASA’s Magnetospheric Multiscale (MMS) spacecraft onboard launches from the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41, Thursday, March 12, 2015, Florida.

item.title: "Mini Supernova" Explosion Could Have Big Impact
item.description: Using NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory, astronomers have studied one particular explosion that may provide clues to the dynamics of other, much larger stellar eruptions.

item.title: NASA's MMS Spacecraft Launches on an Atlas V Rocket
item.description: The United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with NASA’s Magnetospheric Multiscale (MMS) spacecraft onboard launches from the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41, Thursday, March 12, 2015, Florida. NASA’s MMS mission studies the mystery of how magneti

item.title: Expedition 42 Soyuz Landing
item.description: The Soyuz TMA-14M spacecraft is seen as it lands with Expedition 42 commander Barry Wilmore of NASA, Alexander Samokutyaev of the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos) and Elena Serova of Roscosmos.

item.title: Expedition 42 Returns to Earth
item.description: The Soyuz TMA-14M spacecraft is seen as it lands with International Space Station Expedition 42 commander Barry Wilmore of NASA, Alexander Samokutyaev of the Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos) and Elena Serova of Roscosmos near the town of Zhezkazgan, Kazakhstan on March 11, 2015 (March 12 in Kazakhstan).

item.title: Test Firing of Booster for NASA's New Rocket
item.description: The largest, most powerful rocket booster ever built successfully fired up Wednesday for a major-milestone ground test in preparation for future missions to help propel NASA’s Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft to deep space destinations, including an asteroid and Mars.

item.title: Preparing to Test the Booster for NASA's New Rocket
item.description: Engineers at Orbital ATK prepare to test the largest, most powerful booster ever built for NASA's new rocket, the Space Launch System (SLS), which will fire up for a ground test at 11:30 a.m. EDT on Wednesday, March 11, at Orbital ATK Propulsion Systems’ test facilities in Promontory, Utah.

item.title: Taking a Closer Look at Orion After Successful Flight Test
item.description: Engineers across the country have been busy taking a closer look at NASA'S Orion spacecraft and the data it produced during its successful flight test in December 2014.

item.title: Ceres Seen From NASA's Dawn Spacecraft
item.description: This image of Ceres was taken by NASA's Dawn spacecraft on March 1; on March 6, the mission achieved orbit around the previously unexplored world.

item.title: Astronaut Scott Kelly Preparing for Launch on One-Year Mission
item.description: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly is seen inside a Soyuz simulator at the Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center (GCTC), Wednesday, March 4, 2015 in Star City, Russia.

item.title: Island of Hawaii From the International Space Station
item.description: European Space Agency astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti took this photograph of the island of Hawaii and posted it to social media on Feb. 28, 2015.

item.title: The NACA Spirit Captured, 1945
item.description: In this 1945 photo, test pilots (from left) Mel Gough, Herb Hoover, Jack Reeder, Steve Cavallo and Bill Gray stand in front of a P-47 Thunderbolt. The photo was taken at the then-named Langley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory, which was a research facility for the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, or the NACA.
